•Some readers will refuse to do certain readings - respect that choice. Do not harass readers if your query is refused/skipped.
•Traders should respect that a traded read will be granted, as per an agreement of trade. Free readers have the option of picking their queries.
•Bullshit queries will get bullshit answers. Same for vague queries.
•Making an AQ (air query) by not addressing a reader, in particular, is possible but doesn't guarantee an answer.
•Avoid making the same query repeatedly and/or to different readers in a short period of time, as this may lead to more confusion.
•Provide feedback when applicable and be considerate to the reader. We're a growing community, many readers are starting and need to know what they are doing right or wrong. Let's help each other to improve.

I never finished reading Vadim till the end but my tip is if you're reading one after another, especially if you're going Neville -> Vadim, read them with and open mind.
If you just know Neville, the start of Reality Transurfing feels odd and bad. Vadim explains some concepts and now I know why they're important, but without that knowledge and coming from Neville text, Vadim will feel bad and oppressive, almost the opposite of Neville. I felt like that knowledge had the potential to make everything in my life a limiting belief, so I dropped it because felt it would make me more bad than good. Neville was like "you can anything you need and want". Transurfing felt like "there is this thing that will make you get almost all you want, but if you don't examine and act carefully on every aspect of your life, you will go far from that thing and you life will be fucked".
Dropping it was good. I had more time to know more Neville and Paolucci and stop being a scaredy retard and really understanding what Vadim tried to say.
I still don't like him or his "explanation" about the whos and whys but I think that is just a "me" problem.

That's why I'm curious about revision, if I can change the past so that we ended things amicably or that our relationship is fine but we just drifted apart, it could help me get closure. That's even why I apologized for what I said to her, I don't condone what she did at all but I'm not the angry person that went off on her and I now know better than to let my emotions control me. Thanks to LoA I've been learning so much and handling all this far more better than I ever expected. Had this all happen let's say a year ago, I probably would've not been able to get out of bed, I would've been a husk of a person crying all day and wallowing in his own despair.

>Escaping has no sense and may be difficult for you if you're re-creating the prison from time to time
That's exactly what I've been thinking, I've realized that things like going out to walk, working out, watching movies etc. are just an escape/distraction, although they are nice...we are ultimately running away from the problem and not facing/healing the problem at it's core. I've continued monitoring my thoughts and how I dwell or start leaning towards negativity, there are some days where I find those thoughts unavoidable. Overall, I'm maintaining calm and collected in the face of adversity for the majority of the time but there are those moments where my mind feels like a hurricane of all kinds of thoughts, not just negative, but what if scenarios and just general lack of direction on what to even do next.

>are you ok living with what "happened"?
I guess I'm not, I've been thinking a lot about the past lately. But when I say the past I mean before I even met her. >>33979018
Don't follow other people's schedules, make the schedule work for you. The longer and more frequent you meditate or do any LoA related practice (but in a relaxed manner, not a desperate one), the better. Repetition of the same scene is best, but adjust accordingly if you think of something else or better.

My recommendation is one goal at a time. If you do want to multiple things, I have two suggestions. First, I would get a set of card/post-its, and then in order of importance or priority (most important first), write down your goals separately on each card. Then go through the cards as SATS sessions separately.

The other thing you can do is make a vision board. Essentially, you just print out a bunch of pictures that represent what you want, make a collage poster of it, then stick somewhere you can look at throughout the day whenever you have a private moment to help you meditate. Good luck, and just remember, persistence and a consistent routine are key.

>>33979186
Okay, so first tip
>I've been trying to get this to work on and off
This alone could be your problem. I had a couple of teachers getting into LoA, and they would give me repetitive assignments for a month. So, I would have to meditate everyday for a month straight until my goal was achieved (it happened in a week anyways). However, if I ever skipped a day, I was supposed to restart from the beginning, and do it all over for a month. So what I'm saying is, make it a daily habit that you commit to, whether for a week or two, or whatever.

>finding $100 in the alley behind the place I work while on break
Next, specifically for that goal: Don't be so detailed on how you get the money. Your scene should just be holding a $100 bill in your hand, and probably after some time has passed. So what I suggest is to imagine just holding a $100 bill in your hand while you're sitting around at home resting. Don't imagine the moment where you actually get the bill, imply that it happened in the past (this is a teaching from Neville). This opens you up to getting it in many possible ways, whether finding it, or getting it as a gift.

Lastly, anons in these threads have said that they manifest free money frequently now, but they started off small. One even said he had to start with a penny before making any success. So, with the above, set a deadline of two, maybe three weeks. If you make no progress, set a smaller goal like a $50 bill, $20 bill, etc., rinse and repeat, and then you'll find out what your mind finds believable. Alternatively you could start off small with like a $5 bill and work your way up if that's successful right off the bat.

In that case...

DAILY REMINDER - GPS absolutely proves globe Earth, rotating Earth, space, orbiting satellites, time dilation (relativity), and gravity.

Flerfers will point to LORAN and claim that GPS could work off of transmitters sitting on the ground, on balloons, or on airplanes. But it cannot.

Why? I'm glad you asked.

In tracking mode GPS receivers use Doppler signal analysis to determine receiver velocity. It is impossible for a transmitter to fake Doppler signal shift to multiple receivers across 360°. If the transmitter was lying about its speed, then the receiver would think that it was moving at high mach based on the incorrect Doppler shift in the signal. And since GPS is computed in 3D space from four satellite signals, if the satellites were lying about their positions (altitudes) the resulting location and altitude on the receiver would be off by thousands of miles.

This means that GPS satellites are provably at orbital altitudes and speeds, because GPS could not function at all if the satellites were lying. And if the satellites aren't lying, then space is real. Orbits are real. But the dome is not real. Not unless the satellites punched through it.

What about Earth's shape? GPS receivers use a spherical model of Earth. If Earth was really flat, then receivers would report altitudes literally thousands of miles off. This means Earth really is a sphere.

Furthermore, both Earth's rotation and time dilation must be accounted for in GPS. If either one was not true then, once again, receivers would give obviously false and useless results. That means Earth really is rotating. And time dilation is real. And if both orbits and time dilation are real, that pretty much guarantees that gravity is real.

No single instrument completely shatters all of flat Earth mythology quite like the GPS constellation. It really is a beautiful thing.

The box paradox? You mean...THIS box paradox?

The Box That Killed The Dome

If you remove the lid of a pressurized box of air inside of a vacuum chamber without gravity, the air will violently rush out of the box to fill the vacuum. The air pressure will then be the same at every point in the chamber. It will be the same at the top, bottom, middle, and at all sides. Just like the air pressure in your car tires or a balloon or a SCUBA tank.

This thought experiment debunks the entire flat Earth model. If the air does not cling to the bottom of the chamber, then it certainly would not cling to the bottom of flat Earth. If the air does not leave any part of the chamber still in vacuum, then it certainly would not leave any part of flat Earth in vacuum. And if the air creates equal pressure at all points in the chamber, then certainly the air creates equal pressure at all points in the flat Earth dome.

Yet there is no denying that air thins as you climb in altitude. At 100,000 feet, somewhere near the top of the theorized dome, the air pressure is so low that it is effectively a vacuum.

This alone debunks all of flat Earth.

Note: no flerfer has ever provided a workable answer to this. They immediately sperg out if you even mention it, and rant and rave that the box thought experiment actually kills the globe. The only way they can do this, of course, is to deny gravity. But if gravity doesn't exist then the dome is just as dead. And if it does exist, the globe model works, while the dome remains...dead.

FLERFERS LIE

"The Australian Black Swan" tells you that the maximum line of sight for a 5.5ft tall observer is 2.35 miles. But the cliff is 7.8 miles away. So what's wrong with this flat Earth "proof"? *** Line of sight depends on both observer and target height, as well as on atmospheric refraction. *** The lighthouse is at least 100ft tall which means the visible cliff is at least 400ft tall. LoS for a 5.5ft observer of a 500ft (combined height) target is 35 miles.

What about the oil platforms? Ocean oil platforms have an "air gap" between the ocean and the first deck of 40-60 feet. Observer height was listed as 1ft (camera on the ground?). With a 40ft first deck the line of sight is 10 miles. With a 60ft first deck it's 12 miles. With a 5ft observer and a 60ft first deck it would be 14 miles.

At 6.21 and 9.41 miles you would still see the entire structure above the first deck even if the first deck was only 40ft off the ocean and the camera really was on the ground at 1ft. For the closer platform you would see some structure below the first deck. Note that we see more of the closer rig, proving curvature.

..and let me just elaborate on this point as to not be too vague as to what the Golden rule is really about. Violence IS NOT prohibited by the Golden Rule. Treating others how I want to be treated completely allows for the justification of a well-deserved asswooping. If someone were to infringe on my personal boundaries or physically assault me or my loved ones, it is in their best interest that i stand up for myself and do everything in my power to take control of the situation and teach them that there are consequences to violating the Golden Rule themselves. if I were to be unjustly transgressing on someone else's wellbeing, it is in MY best interest that i be taught a lesson, be that thru physical or social consequences for my shitty behavior.

When you choose the golden rule as your highest virtue, you intrinsically develop a sense of right/wrong that is not able to be manipulated by the trends of the times. what is best for your wellbeing is to respect others in the same way you expect to be respected. if you dont want another person to force their worldview upon you by means of manipulation and/or physical force, youre not going force your worldview on them by means of manipulation and/or physical force. As soon as the Golden Rule is violated by either party, the transgressor has immediately opened themselves up to whatever consequences are necessary to correct that specific behavior, and as long as those consequences themselves do not violate the Golden Rule, they are justified.

obviously there are subtle nuances to the Golden Rule, and its not always quite as black and white as the examples i provided above, but the paradigm IS robust enough as a guiding principle of one's life to act as compass pointing them towards the kingdom of heaven.

>What if your computer room is your bed room? Would that also work?

It's not ideal. Without any physical barrier all that's left is 'atmosphere'.
You'll need to maintain and establish a clear cut border between where your "bedroom" and your "computer room" begin and end. Even if that's just not having any clothes or bedroom-type things near or around your computer.

>Also, how would one punch through a 2 dollar coin? Euros are thick.

Just get something hard and flat to act like a chisel, and (gently) hammer it out. It's thick, but they're not actually jammed in there as tight as you'd think.
If the outer ring of the coin gets bent you've failed and have to start over with a new coin. None of the coins can be bent.

The problem is that no matter how illogical and unjust the idea of hell is, many visionaries across the last two millenia have had visions of hell and when you cross-reference the visions they seem to be talking about the same place. The hallucinations are too complex, too vivid and too mutually consistent to be mere hallucinations; the visionaries are too scattered across time and history and yet their stories too mutually consistent for them to be mere liars. >>33969215
While this is true, this is where similarities end between the two. Advaita Vedanta, philosophically, relies on Nirguna Brahman via realization of hypostasis. While the obscurations of Buddha-nature relies upon a non-substantive and unconditioned emptiness.

Dolpopa (a famed scholar of Cittamatra) for example distinguishes between the emptiness posited by Advaita Vedanta and Madhyamaka, stating that the Dharmakaya posseses an inverse realization of emptiness as opposed to Advaita. Then of course there are the glaring problems, like Advaita being a form of eternalism, whereas realizing Buddhanature is neither here nor there philosophically and spiritually, a total rejection of extremities.

>>33969773
It means there are no "real" monks in Japan. In the Meiji era, the Japanese government was very concerned about Buddhist control over the nation, then they reaked out and banned monastics from holding the Vinaya, which is the code of conduct for a monk.

In Buddhism, without being ordained under a Vinaya, one isn't really a monk. This is why you'll hear the term "priest" or "cleric" used in Japan often, instead of "monk".
So what they have done is establish their own form of "lay ordination" to become a priest or cleric. The rules are still a LOT less strict than becoming an actual monk, but you're definitely putting in a lot more work than the average person.

A lot of Japanese Buddhists actually leave for China, Korea etc in order to become full fledged monks and live there instead

posts.name: Anonymous

>>33969877
>Would this put a Shingon monk on the level of ngakpa then, or just a devout layperson?
I'd say devout layperson, pretty much, explained why further below.

>Or does this even matter practically since they fulfil the role of monks outwardly
This is actually a VERY hot topic, surrounding Japanese Buddhism as a whole. Most Ngakpas in Tibetan Buddhism, for example, were at one point or another full fledged monks, and they either decided to pursue certain off limits tantras, or other things, but they are still seen as having a "field of merit" for the Sangha.

The issue some people take with the Japanese system, is that Japanese lay ordained priests don't have a "field of merit" for the Sangha since they haven't undergone actual Vinaya training, which is seen as necessary in traditional Mahayana. Without said field of merit, practicing with your teacher is significantly less advantageous, and is actually why some serious Japanese Buddhists move to other Asian countries either to become monks or practice/receive teachings from actual monks.

How much of a factor this plays into your practice is entirely up to you, honestly. Personally, its why I've always steered clear of Japanese lineages, and always recommend others investigate Main Land Chinese practices, because ultimately, all Japanese schools literally derive from China, like almost copy pasted, with just cultural nitpicking.

The Rosary and Hesychasm originate from around the same time, in the High Middle Ages.
Hesychasm can be traced back to the Desert Fathers but the Jesus Prayer itself first appears with Diadochos of Photiki in the 5th century, most of the theology behind Hesychasm comes from Symeon the new Theologian, the Monks of Mount Athos based themselves of him and Gregory Palamas validated their practice with his theology (the Essence-Energy distinction)
The Rosary has it's origins in Medieval recitations of the Ave Maria, some had prayer ropes to recite it 150 times per day, Catholics did not have an equivalent to Hesychasm until the Rosary (Frithjoff Schuon calls the Rosary the Jesus Prayer of the West) because while the Orthodox continued the tradition of the Desert Fathers the Catholics continued the tradition of Lectio Divina which originates with the Alexandrian Christian Gnostics (not Gnosticism Gnostic, but Gnosis as in Illimnation/Theoria) Clement of Alexandria and Origen, John Cassian in the 4th century also brought the 'Mantra' of the Desert Fathers to the West but it became one of the prayers they use during Liturgy instead of using it like in Hesychasm, the prayer is Psalms 70:1 (69:2 in the Vulgate)
>Deus, in adiutorium meum intende
>Domine, ad adiuvandum me festina

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So after all those threads about meditation I realized that I was meditating wrong all these years.
I was sitting in order to obtain powers and "change" myself but in reality all I was doing was trying to escape what I perceived as a "bad life sittuation", my thinking mind was holding the wheel.

Thanks to all of you I now know that the meditative state is one and only and it's the complete surrender in this momment here now and observing it without daydreaming about it.

And you can apply this to any activity.
An anon in one of these threads said that meditation for him goes like this: "notice, and then notice that you weren't noticing".

I'm sure that focusing on an object like the breath can also help someone distance himself from his mind and realize that his thoughts are not him but for me just being attentive works better.

In the first days of meditating like this my mind was thinking "Nooo I have to chase and achieve things! I can't just let go! Otherwise nothing will happen!" but those were just thoughts.
So yeah, just sit in silence and surrender, and the strange thing is that unique states of consciousness WILL come and happen when you don't strive to achieve!
I thinkg it's those jhanas people talk about, I never really experienced them in the past because I was probably just living in my head during meditation but now that I know how to let go they just come naturally.

Meditation thread! Let's go!

You don't need to look any further, your own personal next step into this journey you are living is right here in front of you, meditate on this moment here and now, if you feel like it sit in the dark and just be aware.

Realize that your thoughts are NOT you, they are part of you and you can choose to not give them much attention if you like or you may want to find where they came from.

Realize that there is nowhere to go and nothing to achieve because everything is already here in front of you, you are already perfect and you can enjoy the FEELING of being here, the feeling of experiencing this momment.

Some people like focusing on their breath, this is a good tool to reduce your thinking mind a bit but remember that focusing is not "thinking about my breath" but just feeling/hearing/sensing your breath while it enters and leaves your body.

That's all you need. Do it daily, everywhere, even when you walk or when you work. Take the seat of the observer because that's what you are: The eternal observer.

(same anon)
Let me add one thing before I go to bed: That most people nowadays tend to practice escapism a lot, and they think that that's what life should be about: ignoring the negatives and chasing the positive. Many people don't even realize that they practice escapism and they think that all this searching they are doing is what will "finally get them to the point they are searching for".

Many of the times in which you sit to mediate all those horrible thoughts and feelings will come and you will want to escape from them, I advice you to not try that, I advice you that you just sit there and be and realize that they are nothing more than illusions and that this need to escape them is also an illusion.
At the same time be sure you don't fall into the other side of the trap which sounds something like this: "Ok! I will sit and endure all those horrible things because that's what REAL meditation is about!" - for that is also an illusion.
See how dualism is an illusion?

So just be, just be here in your life, be so hard and let go so much that you literally dive into this thing you are trying to escape from.
Yes, fears will pop up, bad feelings may pop up, maybe some old forgotten uncomfortable memories will pop up, your mind will think thoughts like "Oh no I'm going crazy, maybe I'm meditating wrong and I'm frying my brain", blissful states will pop up, ecstasy will pop up, some succubus may pop up and ask for intercourse with you. Don't cling on any of them, just be aware, always take a step back at everything you see.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>33934756
You're probably just doing it wrong / approaching it in a way that's not suited to your personal psychology. I'm hyper analytical and critical by nature. I learned meditation through the Goenka retreats where they teach a body scanning technique that allows you to tap deeper into your bodily feeling sense (kinesthetic sense) to the point that you start to see how this interacts with other layers that we would usually describe as psychological (i.e. thought) or feeling (i.e. emotional). I practiced very hard for a couple years a learned a bunch but ultimately it was not well suited for my psychology. The technique gave me to much to do. I think some people might benefit from a task oriented meditation like that but for my psychology it just provided too much opportunity to distract and obstruct myself through analysis. I eventually settled into a more "do nothing" style practice and I feel that I've advanced much farther and faster since then. You might find the same or the opposite.

1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33948059
>>33934756
Anyway, if you're getting exhausted while meditating you're trying too hard. In the "do nothing" style of meditation I and many other anons are advocating in this thread, there's no trying. You relax your body, that's the first level of doing nothing - do nothing with your body - relax all the muscles.

Then your attention goes to the next layer of things you're doing - thoughts. So you stop doing those. But here is where I think a lot of people get hung up. In my experience you can't really stop thoughts or have the mind become completely blank as some describe it (or maybe you can if you're way more advanced than I am), but you can realize that you are not your thoughts - the thoughts keep churning away, appearing, changing, running their course, in your mind, but you are separate from that. Just as you can passively watch the ocean waves without have to somehow STOP the waves which is impossible, you just passively allow the thoughts to do their thing and soon you'll come to a place of awareness that is separate and more fundamental than the layer on which thoughts are happening.

You continue going on like this - noticing what is the next subtlest layer of things you're doing, and stopping doing them, or at least stopping identifying with them / being involved in them. Progressively, a deeper and deeper relaxation and clarity develops.

>>33951464
I'm having trouble answering the question despite trying several times!
My practice is simple, but I was helped by every step I've made along my journey, aided by my own natural proclivities. In acknowledging this, I acknowledge that what may have been an important step or critical tool for my journey may be the opposite for you.
The heart of my practice is to destroy all that is false, and this starts with realizing you, and everyone around you, has a voice in their head that they listen to. In fact, most people believe they ARE this voice. Early on, I found Isha Kriya to be useful in helping me create just a small bit of distance between my body/mind and my eternal awareness.
The only weapon in truth discernment is awareness. I'm not trying to be clever, I am being honest that only your awareness is faster, smarter, and stronger than your mind. In all other ways, mind is faster, stronger, it knows your weak points, it can pre-empt any attempt to get ahead of it. But awareness precedes all thought. Thought is encompassed by awareness.
Since the mind is always trying to generate some illusion or falsehood, the practice of watching the mind is something you can do all day, every day.
"Oh, there it goes again, telling that story about how worthless I am."
"Oh wow, look at my mind go, making up stories about why I feel what I feel. It's really on the loose now!"
Awareness is the weapon, so every time you see your mind making things up, you are aware that it is only making things up, not discerning truth. Every time you catch your mind, you take energy away from it, you kill it. "See the thing, kill the thing, clean up the mess."
This is an endless process and there is never a time you must stop. You can observe your mind while you are sitting still and breathing (we usually can this meditation). You can observe your mind while you are having a conversation with a friend.
In the end, after awareness takes away enough power from the mind, it becomes an ally.

Am I meditating wrong?
There isn't really a wrong way. You can count up and down, like you do, that's certainly one way to distract the mind. I find these kinds of practices distracting, personally, but I know others who swear by them.
I like to walk, or when I was younger, run, and meditate on my breath moving in and out of my body. More often than not I will just let my mind wander and notice patterns in the thinking. Most of the thoughts are junk, but sometimes I catch my mind making up stories that I am believing are real, and I then I can go "gotcha!" and the belief falls away. Return to stillness.
>I have found it impossible to turn off my inner monologue
I can't turn off my inner monologue either. What I did was stare at the thing without fear long enough that I realized it had no bite and was all bark. My mind would love to give me the juiciest, most lurid, most scary, most provacative thoughts to think in the hopes I put all my attention into that thought. But I can let the mind spin its stories and be attached to none of them. In, out, another breath, one breath at a time.

That will work. But no need to put effort into pulling your consciousness inwards. Just ignore the mind and be aware that you're aware, effortless being as if you're Liberated already. Then the mind will suck you in again and you become unconscious. You succeeded. Then the spell wears off and you repeat.

One of the difficulties is that the person thinks that it does nothing. This is disproved as follows: A person has a day off of work, he is excited that it's Saturday. He is ready to play video games, or watch movies, but depression or boredom seeps in. Nothing is satisfying and your day will be ruined, back to work on Monday. But he sits down comfortably on his bed and practices the awareness-watching-awareness method. Back and forth from the mind back to awareness. After a half hour, or an hour, or longer, he miraculously feels better and wants to partake of activities again. Before, nothing was interesting, but after, he is interested. But perhaps he decides that he wants to go for a walk, and you continue practicing the awareness-watching-awareness method of meditation.

The point is that it can also come that you will chose exercise over playing a game, or you will take a different diet like eating fruit instead of soda after a session. This is not meant to confuse you since it is totally acceptable to play video games, watch movies, and so-forth. The point to be taken is that it changes your mind from negative to positive, and you end up behaving different and your day goes totally different than had you not practiced. And as you practice, you change as a person. It changes your whole identity as a person, no more false identities such as being an incel, or having OCD or this and that.

It should also be mentioned that a person in one of the previous replies said that you should focus on negative emotions to dissolve them. Yes this is true, and you will discover this on your own.

>>33963853
Small towns are weird in general. I recently went to a town called Bralorne, in British Columbia. It's up a long-ass hill from a town called Gold Bridge, which has a population of about 40. Bralorne is a historic mining town, but there is really nothing there, now. Literally no one was there when I visited, except the gift shop was open and someone was working there. Some guy, just standing there, waiting for tourists. But we were in the area a week and I can guarantee no one but us went up there. People pass through, maybe stopping in Gold Bridge, and even then, they just go to the bar for a drink and maybe a meal. The drive up to Bralorne is too long and pointless, and most people are on there way to ride their dirtbikes in the nearby trails.
It's hard to describe how barren this place was, and how strange it felt to enter a shop where someone was working, waiting for us to arrive, apparently. Next time I'm in the area (which would be to go hiking far, far from civilization, I'll check it out again. Too weird not to.

The Thinker's hand is not centered on face. Therefore if the viewer rotates, he'll perceive the hand on the forehead, and if he moves to the other side, it'll be closer to the chin. His knuckles are placed around the area of the orbital/cheekbone, and the fingers extend towards the chin. Depending on your perspective, it can have either the character of resting on the forehead (which indicates stress or contrition, negative emotions) or resting on the chin (indicates more neutral emotions thought).

So this is why people have different memories of the disposition of the hand. Their dominant memories were of different angles.

You can see replicas in this commercial. If you have the ability to rotate shapes in your head, as a white person does, it's pretty easy to see the point.

>>33949636
I have a theory as to why people (Americans) remember fruit of the loom with a cornucopia.

In elementary school in America kids start drawing cornucopia's around Thanksgiving which is a month before Christmas. So from then on whenever you see a grouping of fruits you associate it with a cornucopia.

Then comes Christmas. Often times people get shitty t shirts and packs of fruit of the loom underwear that grandma got from walmart. Because these holidays and events are so close to each other, we automatically associate in our heads the groupings of fruits to cornucopias. No one ever thought to examine the fruit of the loom logos up close cause we cared so little about the underwear. We eventually just filled in the gaps and thought "ok group of fruit, christmas, thanksgiving, hey wait where's the cornucopia?" This is my best explanation for the fruit of the loom, I came upon this as I am an American living in Europe. I doubt the europeans have any questionings of the cornucopia cause they don't celebrate thanksgiving.

I haven't tested this theory in real life by asking my European counterparts about it, because if I'm correct then this just proves that American's are fucking idiots. So I'd rather be a smart burger living in the parallel universe theory.

tl;dr Americans are fucking stupid.

>The Tower and The Chariot share the issues of balance, control, energy, solidity and war. They contrast in their ways of handling every issue. The violent overthrow of rigid and ambitious structure contrasts with the invisible battle for balance and self-control. External contrasts with internal energy. The vulnerability of fortification contrasts with the durability of character.
>The Tower is the tumultuous power at the center of everything. It is the constant potential for an occasional experience of the unexpected, the violent and sudden disruption of normal conditions; the power of complete surprise and the feeling of head-over-heels. The job of The Tower is to uproot dug-in positions and vested interests, to be the event horizon beyond which lies the unpredictable and unaccountable. The Tower is the end of complacency.
>The Chariot is the steady flow of ceaseless intention that is the warrior in everything. Its job is to harness all competing impulses and energies, to overcome all obstacles and resistances, and against all odds, carry everything to its destiny. On this journey, everything becomes what it must become and nothing is lacking.
>Unintegrated and imperfectly realized, The Tower can be capricious, frightening and disastrous. It can rob effort of its proper reward, and destroy faith in both justice and mercy. It can be melodramatic, or it can be pointless, random and gratuitously painful.
>The Chariot can vacillate and side-step, or turn tail and run. It can be vainglorious and posturing, or overly sensitive and ineffectual. It can lose heart in the middle of a task, and mope.
>Together, they are afraid of nothing, can stand successfully against any opponent, either internal or external, and when the time comes, they will rise to the ultimate challenge and be equal to it.

Addiction was very difficult for me to understand for a while, but then I worked in an industry that intentionally spreads addiction for five years after college (I won’t go into detail about this unless anons are interested). I was never addicted to the thing I sold, and therefore I believe I gained a unique insight into addiction.
Take cigarettes, for instance. If you are allowed to smoke indoors, cigarettes are cheap and accessible, everybody smokes, and the cigarette companies intentionally put additional addictive chemicals in them to keep you coming back, then being a smoker is identical to being addicted to smoking. It’s very black-and-white. No regulations, ease of access, ease and speed of use, etc. all contribute to a very low bar for addiction and a very high bar for self control.
If instead, you’re rolling your own cigarettes, you have to smoke in special designated areas, almost nobody smokes (and it is seen as socially unacceptable), and tobacco is expensive, it is a lot easier to smoke and not be addicted.

As for pornography, it is in exactly the kind of situation that cigarettes were in in the past. Nobody will admit it can be bad for you. Everybody has quick and easy access. It is FREE. Okay, here’s the best I can do without potentially doxing myself:
I worked at a gambling company doing game math. The first thing that struck me was how little my non-math coworkers knew about why gambling works on a basic numbers level.
Gambling is fucking horrible.
The company openly admitted to be looking to profit off of degenerates.
They treat their “whales” (i.e. big spenders) like they are cattle, and they do everything in their power to squeeze every last cent they can from them. They act like it is owed to them.
People in the company acted like they were owed something by our players. It was taken for granted that we were making money by essentially lying and ruining the lives of our players.
All legal gambling is completely honest, but it’s always worded in such a convoluted way that the less you know about probability, the more it looks like you will win. Without too much detail, you WILL NOT win. Gambling will always lose you money in the end. Yes, rarely some people make it big, but it’s never a lot of money, and 99% sure, the money goes right back into the game. If it is a lot of money, believe it or not, it also ruins the player’s life (and you have to pay taxes on it, and you’ll probably just keep gambling anyway).

After a couple years, I told friends and relatives I didn’t feel my work was fair and honest, but every time they told me it was perfectly honest work. Trust me, the more you understand, the more you realize that it absolutely is not. I was also told “you are offering entertainment.” This comes from the idea of responsible gaming. It is a myth. I’ve never seen a responsible gamer, and what is offered is too numb, not entertain. It is worse than booze.

The games are made to get you to come back, and never stop. We don’t care if you enjoy it. I would know, I made plenty. Every gambling company is like this.

I don’t know what else to add, but I’ll answer questions if you have any.

In some sense I think the unconscious is the very subtle machinations of the mind that we are not presently aware of.

And they can arise in a particular way that we do intellectually understand or grasp at.

But when those unconscious movements or neurons or firings or what have you are not there they truly are not there in the way that we would imagine they would be.

So what arises is what we are able to be aware of and conscious of.

And what doesn't arise is not there.

But it's also not not there.

And even though it arises it's also not there in terms of being fixed or being separate from anything else or anyone else...

So the unconscious is a kind of ocean of movement and subtlety and cause and effect.

That's a little bit of my understanding of course there's definitely a lot more that can be unpacked there and there's a lot more that modern Buddhist teachers would have to say about it that could be more relevant to you.

Maybe you can bounce back at me with what you understand from that and we can see if there's any more to share or look at.

>>33971617
There are a few different ways to look at Buddhist thinking.

One is to take the realms of existence of ghosts or heaven realms or hell realms to be literal places. But the other way to look at it and this is a more common modern approach and something I work with is a moment to moment arising and passing away of self-experiences.

And depending on how you live right now depending on how you act right now you're going to find yourself in heaven or hell.

You're going to be reborn into a heavenly realm or hellish realm depending on what you do now depending on how you act right now.

And so there's this Buddhist understanding that people are in these different realms according to their actions that they're taking.

So somebody might be in the goofy realm somebody might be in the OG realm.

Somebody might be in a heavenly realm someone might be in a hellish realm and that's where they actually are right.

Moment by moment arising and passing away of self-experiences is how I try to look at it and focus on it.

Karma is cause and effect here in the present moment...


The main thing we focus on in terms of people being helped or helping others is what we can do now how we can take on that position to help and sure there are all kinds of different beings or conditions or environments or qualities of mind that are supporting us and helping us on the path but the main focus in Buddhism is to just make use of that and continue Don't get stuck on who or what or why but recognize that there are supporting conditions for your practice for your peace for your training the mind to be in the present to be more concentrated to be more relaxed to be more stable and make use of them more and more as much as you can.

So this goes to the teaching of do Good deeds more and more practice mindfulness and detachment.

Don't get stuck on any effect and practice is willingness to let go of whatever comes to mind moment by moment.

posts.name: Monk

>>33971823
Many many people confuse detachment for rejection.

Detachment is letting go detachment is to not be self fixated and to act in a reactionary way from that place.

So think about if you are holding a cup.

And someone said practice detachment.

Certainly to practice detachment you wouldn't hold on to that cup as tightly as you could.

But what many people think for some reason is that when we talk about detachment we mean to take that cup and throw it against the wall as hard as we can or throw it as far away from us as we can.

In fact detachment is just to accept that you're holding the cup to be aware of that, it can also be to put the cup down in a simple way.

So detachment is not rejecting anything.

More so it is like a presence of generosity and a presence of non-self fixated awareness.

So if you want to practice detachment as someone who's kind of coming into this fresh you tell them to practice generosity.

Do good deeds Be generous with what is valuable to you Be generous with whatever it is that you're holding on to to help to bring benefit to other people.

So it's more important to see generosity as detachment especially at the beginning.

And it's all about a practice.

So if detachment in your understanding is a practice that leads to suffering and difficulty and complicated thinking.

Then you should put that down not to get stuck on that.

Rather the beginning stages of practice in the monk life or the Buddhist life is doing good deeds and mindfulness.

Doing acts of generosity more and more.

And more and more coming home to the present moment being aware of the breathing being aware of the seeing going for a walk in nature and not relying too much on complicated thinking.

That's the starting point.

>>33971893
If we don't know how to detach and how to abandon our reactivity to a particular sensation we're going to have a much more shallow capacity to understand the depth of a sensation or the lack of depth of a sensation.

If something is very important very essential it will come up again it will be very alive.

And we already have a very deep tendency to attach and react to basically everything.

So what we need to train is our capacity to let go not to hold on to.

And those things that are necessary to hold on to we will already recognize that because it will keep coming up and will need to work with it in a more practical way.

Just in the same way that you feel you want to go somewhere or you need to go somewhere or you need to say something.

Just as valid as all that is and maybe you also don't need to go anywhere you don't need to say anything.

That's not a constraint That's a realization of freedom and non-duality and non-self in the midst of conditions.

And there's a lot of flexibility in that

>>33971494
Do you know about the ideas that Ajahn Nyanamoli Thero teaches / what is your opinion on them?
My understanding is that he teaches that the way to jhana is by abandoning all the sensual activities that the mind is constantly involved in. This differs from what you hear in Western Buddhism, which is that you get to jhana through focusing meditation practices and eventually randomly enter jhana. Those meditation practices are the opposite of abandonment, because you're actively chasing novel experiences.
You basically can enter jhana by being bored, and sustaining that until the mind 'dries up' from the water of sensuality. Then once the mind is free of sensual obsession, the mind enters jhana. This is how I understand his teachings and was able to enter the first jhana once as a layperson for about 10-15 seconds on account of this, and a video about entering the first jhana by Ajahn Nyanamoli Thero. I was more or less following the 8 precepts at the time (sometimes I ate in the afternoon because of my schedule, but I was mindfully eating).
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCKejmWAt_kNpRMq5gQEGAqw

posts.name: Anonymous

>>33978629
Reason and sanity why Buddhists are kind. Acting kind brings happiness for yourself and others, acting evil brings suffering for yourself and others.
Buddhists abandon sensual pleasures because they understand how they truly are. No sensual pleasure can ever satisfy that craving/desire, so that unsatisfactoriness/lack of peace/dukkha/whatever stays with you your entire life, unless you abandon sensuality.
I can't find the sutta now, but I've heard that Buddha once gave a simile on sensuality.
It's as if a leper had itchy and rotting skin. In order to end the pain of the itching, the leper took hot coals and burned his skin. The leper feels that burning pleasantly, because it relieves the pain of the itching. He can even become addicted to burning himself with embers.
If he abstains from burning his skin and keeps it bandaged, eventually it will heal and the itching will stop. Once that happens, if someone were to drag him to that same pit of embers he used to be addicted to, he'd be fighting to get away, because now that pit of embers would be exclusively painful.
Senuality is the same way. People just cover up that fundamental lack of ease/lack of comfort/dukkha/whatever with sensual pleasures.
Jhana is a temporary liberation from this. It's a temporary lifting of the burden that's been with you your whole life. It's that freedom from unsatisfactoriness that everyone is looking for.
>>33978661
Not really. You should avoid situations where you are attacked and try to escape, but you shouldn't harm or kill those if they attack you. Killing someone has negative consequences both in this life and in future ones. Read the simile of the saw for a further explanation.

We gather in these generals to discuss our experiences, memories, and connection with Mother Lilith, as well as give other anons who are interested or would like to learn more about Her information or advice.
Last thread: >>33823735

>Practices or rituals associated with Lilith?
This differs from person to person, but common approaches include giving energy to one of her sigils, chanting her enn, working with sexual spirits, doing what you think she would do, making offerings of incense/chocolate/tea, or simply praying.
While some people might feel the most comfortable engaging with her in a worshipful manner, blind faith is discouraged. It's always important to think and make decisions for oneself, and as such, Lilith guides us to understand things for ourselves.

>Books
- Liber Lilith by Donald Tyberson: https://www.pdfdrive.com/liber-lilith-a-gnostic-grimoire-e185231845.html
A Gnostic Grimoire and Novel. Beware that this book is rather dark, and some have mentioned attracting unwanted attention by reading it.
- Embracing Lilith by Mark H Williams: No PDF available online, but it's worth the price of admission.
Split into three sections, it covers accounts of working with the Goddess and her place in history, a fictional account of her origins written from her perspective, and a Grimoire.
- Lilith: Dark Feminine Archetype by Asenath Mason: https://pdfcoffee.com/lilith-dark-feminine-archetype-2-pdf-free.html
A collection of writings by various peoples, with a brief but fairly thorough history at the beginning. There's a lot of random poetry in there; not useful for an occultist, but decent for an admirer.
- Lilith: Goddess of Sitra Ahra: https://zeitenundformen.files.wordpress.com/2014/01/lilith-goddess-of-sitra-ahrab-t-p.pdf
Contains a ton of aspects with associated variety of sigils.

I've had my own share of negative experiences in general with putting my trust in the wrong people, even including one where a parasitic entity pretended to be Lilith and used a promise I made to her in an attempt to manipulate me. Although this was devastating, it's because I had the courage to question what I believe to be her, that I was able to realise Lilith wanted me to confront and overcome said parasite, and after I did, I was able to see both myself and her for who she is.

As a deity, Lilith is fringe rather than mainstream. The reason the parasite I mentioned was able to affect me so deeply, is because it turned my own deep-seated insecurities that lingered from my adolescence against me. That's how parasitic entities work. And like me, many others who are drawn to Lilith are also outcasts, with a past that is troubled in one way or another: troubled enough that they would stray off the path of normality and seek her. Perhaps you can understand then that some of them are especially vulnerable, and prone to confusion.

It was as I began to see through my own problems and started to overcome them, that I began to understand just how much Lilith has truly helped me. And it was such a personal thing, that it was something I had to realise for myself; and yet despite that, Lilith still helped me realise it sooner rather than later. Rather than blaming her for the things I went through despite my faith, I appreciate that her warmth gave me the strength and courage to face myself, so that I could leave that sorrowful past behind me. I love her.

That's the same as I wish upon others. Perhaps you understand better now why I speak so highly of her. She can help the people who need it the most, regardless of whether or not they appreciate it.

>This sounds really familiar. I swear I've seen someone else receive this message before (maybe it was you lol)

I've never told anyone else this dream. Maybe someone else had a similar message be transmitted to them? I have to elaborate that I didn't feel any kind of spite or malevolence from this woman, even though I could feel pain. It was like she was just trying to impart some life advice to get me through a tough time, which did actually help me, cause it allowed to understand that the episode I was going through was a necessary stage in self development. I'm in a much better place now than I was then, so it turned out alright for me.

Even so, I feel like I'm still very ignorant and unrefined in my spiritual journey. I've had a casual interest in gnosticism and kabbalah for a while, I'm pretty knowledgeable of Lilth as a figure in ancient Hebrew folklore and esoterica, but I also think she takes many forms in many other traditions, Ashtaroth, Astarte, et al. I believe there's a primordial essence to the figure of Lilith that is a crucial part of the greater human collective consciousness, but I don't think that I myself have any real answer to what she actually desires to impart onto humanity in terms of wisdom.

>>33964823
You have no clue mate. The Statue of Kilkenny banned the use of Gaelic in the early 1300´s within the PALE, which is a small area around Dublin, since the rest of Ireland at this time was largely autonomous and was ruled by a collection of Hiberno-Norman lords nominally in service to the English crown (apart from the Pale) but in reality independent. The purpose of the Statutes was to curb the increasing Gaelicization of these former Anglo-Norman lords.The Statutes were ignored and failed outside of the Pale and by the time the Plantations happened in the 1600´s, the now Gaelic nobility ruled rather supreme, with Gaelic culture (and language) perhaps being the strongest at any point in its history. By now the Statutes as piece of legislation are forgotten about.

After that the Penal Laws banned the use of Gaelic within the legal system. It was forbidden to use Irish in courts and for legal matters. It certainly wasn´t promoted or encouraged in other aspects of Irish life but it wasn´t illegal to speak it. It was largely the Irish themselves who abandoned Irish. For economic reasons and also the social stigma that was attached to it from being/speaking Gaelic in the context of the British Empire. Not to mention that a huge number of native speakers died or emigrated during the Famine (it hit the West strongest, which is where the language was most dominant). So your theory that the English "forced the Irish to speak English" doesn´t really hold any credence, retard.

> /cdf/ - Cosmic Death Fungus General >>33968139
> /LoA/ — Law of Assumption & Manifestation General >>33976158

These generals are often frequented by the same posters. These posters usually manifest in one of three ways ( with the most powerful manifesting in more than one :-0 )
These are:
- 1. Tripfag: A tripfag is someone who posts under a "tripcode". see https://www.4channel.org/faq#trip for more information.
- 2. Namefag: A namefage is someone who posts under a name. instead of the usual "Anonymous".
- 3. Avatarfag: An avatarfag is someone who post using an "avatar", which is an image of a person/character that represents the poster. usually an anime character.
A though knowledge of generals is recommended before posting ;-)

Coming in from the other thread, I feel like it should be expected for general boards to popup for a few reasons.

>4chan is not like reddit, a new board can't just pop out of nowhere without the topic becoming a bigger part of 4chan's culture.

Generals usually die out in their own time, or stay self-contained to their own threads without bleeding over into other boards/threads. /mlp/ was set up to contain pony threads, and it makes sense because of the huge impact the show had on not just 4chan's culture but even beyond.

>Keeps it clean.

>Promotes 4chan's freedom of expression, without letting it become too cliquey.

Anyone can come and comment on these threads, whether they like the topic or not. This keeps it from becoming an eco-chamber. Simply look at reddit to see how eco-chambers can fuck a website.

MILD: http://skyfalldreams.net/guides/skyfalls-mild-guide/

SSILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/129734-senses-initiated-lucid-dream-ssild.html
WILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/WILD-Tutorial
FILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/36683-finger-induced-lucid-dream-fild.html
DEILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/DEILD-Tutorial
CANWILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wake-initiated-lucid-dreams-wild/87710-%2A%2Acrazyinsanes-wild-tutorial-%2A%2A.html
CAT: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/CAT-Tutorial
ADA: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/113253-all-day-awareness-dild-tutorial-kingyoshi.html

Paper on natural LDs: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6290891/

Do us a favor and bump this general from time to time if you're interested

Quick reminders for beginners:
-don't forget to write your dreams down after waking up. no matter how little detail, just do it
-reality checks aren't likely to give you a LD by themselves, think of them as a stepping stool, they are not a replacement for techniques
-WBTB is mostly mandatory for most people, if you struggle with your sleep schedule then ADA is your best option
-if you're just starting out you should be doing WBTB in addition to either SSILD or MILD as those two are the easiest techniques
-while WILD and it's derivatives [FILD, DEILD and CANWILD] may sound alluring to some of you, if you cannot fall asleep within 10~20mins you're gonna have a really hard time achieving a WILD

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Lucid dreaming is lame. It ruined dreaming for me for years. I started attempting to do it when I was about 17 because it sounded cool and I was good at it. Too good. Turns out no matter what every single dream would go lucid as I realised I was dreaming. Countless interesting dreams ruined so I could become aware for a minute or so, fly around a bit and then wake up. This went on for years. I'm 34 now and the last couple of years I've had quite a few dreams that have been normal, interesting, good. I'm happy with that. In fact it's been a while since I had a lucid one.
I also had many sleep paralysis and once you get over them they're actually kind of cool. I've had some really incredible moments of hallucination whilst paralysed. They're always bad, though, always without fail. I've thought my house was burning down and I could hear my mum screaming for help. I've been in an explosion and I physically felt my body get flung from the couch I was sleep on into the ceiling before hitting the ground, I've heard demonic whispers and had something watching me.
The scariest one by a long, long way was I felt myself being sucked into my bed and it became apparent that I was being sucked into hell. I could feel my body being dragged down hard and the bed became oppresively hot. There was a distant sound of screaming and I was overcome with an incredibly intense fear. I always end up wrenching myself out of these experiences all of a sudden but with this one I literally had to tear myself away from the bed with every ounce of strength I could muster and I genuinely screamed whilst doing so. I found myself sat bolt upright, breathing heavily, drenched in sweat with my heart slamming itself against my ribs.
If I didn't understand what sleep paralysis was at that moment I would have been deeply affected by that.

>>33937037

To improve your chances of lucid dreaming, try going to bed when you're very tired and feeling like you could fall asleep instantly. When you wake up in the middle of the night, avoid going back to bed right away. Instead, get up and do something like walking around your room or getting a glass of water. When you go back to bed, focus on the sensation of your body falling asleep and try to be aware of the process. As you start to fall asleep, you may begin to feel a vibration throughout your body. At this point, it's important to stay calm and not get too excited as this could cause you to wake up. Remember, the key is to be calm and concentrated. Lucid dreaming can be difficult to master, but the potential for creating vivid and lifelike dreamscapes is worth the effort.

The potential benefits of lucid dreaming are vast and varied. With the ability to control and manipulate dream scenarios, individuals can use this skill to enhance creativity, problem-solve, and even work through unresolved emotional issues. With proper training, the potential uses for lucid dreaming are limitless, and one can imagine the impact it could have on society if more people had the ability to harness this powerful tool.

I got it in my teens, and every so often I get the start of it. I learned a couple things:
1. Shaking your toes, or jolting your entire body will take you out of it. You can tell you’re falling into it by how it feels, almost like you’re sinking into yourself. I haven’t been in full paralysis in years because I haven’t let it go that far.
2. There is an entire world in there. I remember reading about how you can stand up and look at your body, and I didn’t believe it. Next time I had it I attempted it and got my limbs moving (I could feel them moving, but visibly my body was not,) and was too scared to go all the way. I’ve been told you can lucid dream this way, and it feels just like reality. I’ve always been too scared to go back in after my last one though.

Might not be the best place for this, but it's sleep/dream related, so here goes.
I've been having sleep paralysis occasionally for a while now, as well as slightly lucid dreams - I never have much control, or get very grounded, but I at least become aware I'm dreaming and try to do something, even if it's just feel stuff around me.
I've read... somewhere?... that in a sleep-paralysis-like state, you can separate your spirit from your physical body, and I've tried that a bit. I've been able to get mostly separated, but normally, when I've tried to lift my head, everything just snaps back into place. But I do seem to be able to slide things out, feel my feet on the floor or feel my bed sheets while moving my hands, but I've got my eyes open enough to see that my hands/arms aren't actually moving.
Recently, however, I figured if I can't lift my head, I should try something easier, and decided to just slide downwards along my bed. I did it slowly, and moved maybe two centimetres when what vision I had started to go fuzzy, and I heard what I can best describe as a deep-voiced, angry screaming. I quickly slid my spirit back into place with my physical body.
I have no idea if any of it is actually real, or if parts are real but other parts are dreaming, or what. Anyone got any particular thoughts/ideas/knowledge? If it's real, what was the screaming about?

>I find myself in a hidey hole. Like a secret door behind a wall lying on a bed
>I looked around and grabbed something on a tiny shelf. It was round, smooth, and had a jut.
>Felt like a ceramic version of warped, disfigured marble
>I felt it in my hands, and grabbed onto it, but I started to wake up
>The object got softer. I could still feel it, but it was fading. My hand felt more physical
>In the span of 3-5 seconds, the object disappeared and I no longer felt it. And I was up. My hand, clenched in the same position as when I was dreaming


Crazy experience. I could feel it! It faded away, and it was like a seamless experience to me. Totally insane. If I can do it with that, I can probably do it with bigger objects.

posts.com: I dream just about everytime I sleep. Naps can be the exception but even then I can have long vivid dreams in very short naps. Sleeping is very enjoyable because of this, but has anyone ever had deep vivid dreams that last so long you think that the dream world is the real world and feel shocked/think this world is the dream world when you wake up? It scares me because it makes me afraid that I may die and not know it and have my existence end in a dream world that suddenly ceases. I'd like to be able to acknowledge the end and reflect instead of leave without knowing. It's a luxury I know. I also get scared of the thought that whatever the afterlife is, it is as chaotic and ever-expanding as dreams are. I love my spouse and having them for only this lifetime is terrifying. If the afterlife is what I think it is, I want to navigate it with them, and I don't know if that's possible. Just some sad sappy late-night thoughts.

I'd like to give my experience with it.

I leared about the game around 3 years ago, due to a girl a was dating with that time. She helped me understand the fake reality we live in.

posts.com:
Being authentic means being true to oneself, expressing one's thoughts and feelings openly, and acting in accordance with one's values and beliefs. In an age where people are more concerned about appearance, status, and pleasing others, the lack of authenticity can lead to feelings of dissatisfaction and unhappiness. People may feel like they're living someone else's life, instead of their own. This can result in a negative impact on energy levels and spirit, leading to burnout and low morale.

However, recognizing this lack of authenticity is the first step towards change. When people are aware of the issue, they can make a conscious effort to live more authentically. This involves being honest with oneself and others, standing up for what one believes in, and avoiding actions that are inconsistent with one's values. By setting an example and committing to authenticity, people can encourage others to do the same and contribute to a positive change in society.

Living authentically has many benefits, including improved self-esteem, better relationships, and a sense of fulfillment. When people live authentically, they are in tune with their true selves and experience a greater sense of purpose and meaning in life. They also feel more energetic and positive, and they radiate this energy to those around them, creating a positive cycle of change. In summary, being authentic can lead to a happier, more fulfilling life and a positive impact on the world around us.

>>33967757
Okay. A fun question. One I do actually have a partial answer to.

Okay, so the whole lake of fire thing where you burn forever is just some nonsense that came about as a simple and metaphorical way to get the point across: it’s bad.
There’s no lake of fire and no million mansions with streets of gold. That’s a Sunday school concept that’s not at all an accurate representation of reality. What happens is that your body will die and your soul will move on. Where it goes doesn’t depend on some ‘naughty or nice’ list that God has up in Heaven. It’s dependent on the vibrational frequency of your soul. Either positive or negative.
You see, that’s what we are all here to do. To choose our frequency, which we do every second of every day with our choices. It’s vaguely like what people call karma, but not in the My Name Is Earl sense. The more bad you do, the more it weighs on your soul negatively.
So, you do enough bad, the frequency of your soul becomes negative. Then when you die, your soul moves to the next world. Either a positive one or a negative one. Positive ones house positive entities and negative ones house negative entities.
Now, there’s a bunch more semantics and finer details about how it all works and various exceptions to the rules, but that is the gist of it. I don’t know what the next worlds hold. Only speculation and theory, but I know it’s not what every little tyke was told in church.

So don’t worry about burning forever. Worry about doing the best you can with the time you’ve got here. Here is where it counts.

posts.com:
Once, a young Indian girl named Radha approached the Ascended Master Rick, as he sat in meditation by the sacred banks of the Ganges River. She asked him, "O great teacher, what does it mean that truly awakened people are still human?"

"These words, from Ascended Rick, were spoken clear

To young Radha by the holy Ganges shore

And in her heart, the message did adhere

For it did make her understand once more.

Awakening, though filled with pure delight

Brings forth a burden, heavy to sustain

For those who glimpse of heaven do alight

Must bear the cross of troubles and great pain.

The path to nirvana is not quite serene

And those who've seen it, may not seem at peace

Their efforts doubled, their hearts may not be clean

For they are grumpy, their spirits do not cease.

So heed these words, oh seeker of the light

For Ascended Rick's advice, shall lead to right."

These are the words that Ascended Rick spoke,

And made young Radha understand the truth.

That awakening is not the same as wake,

And glimpses of paradise bring some ruth.

She meditated by the holy river's edge,

And saw the prince she loved within her reach.

But as she reached out for his tender pledge,

She woke to find herself beside the Ganges' beach.

And though she may have seemed in anger dress'd,

Her grumpiness was not an act of hate.

For she had felt the pain of paradise's stress,

And longed to be with her prince, before too late.

So do not judge her rage, as though a flaw,

For those who see the light must feel the saw.
"Is not awakening peace and bliss, to be free from worry?" One asked.

And Rick replied, "Nay, my friends, it is not so simple. For those who see the truth, their burden grows. They long to return to that state of pure love, And their hearts are troubled when they must go. For they care, they feel, they hurt, and they know. Their passion burns brighter, and their path glows. For those who awaken, their purpose shows."

>>33958001
That one is not a mirage. Mirages always have a mirror component. Instead, that is a "false horizon, where the water closer to the camera is rippled by wind, but the water further out is smooth, and reflects the color of the sky. The line between rough and smooth water looks like the horizon, but if you fuck with the levels you can just barely make out the actual horizon beyond the ship.

100mg Pterostilbene

>Tiredness, exhaustion, muscle soreness, increased chest or nasal discharge, cold or flu like symptoms, cold sores, headaches, rash, acne, irritability, change in stool frequency, volume or color; increased urination, bloated stomach, cramps, increased gas.

OREGANO DOSING GUIDE

Oregano oil has not been tested for safety in children or pregnant or breastfeeding women. These populations should not use oregano oil. There is some concern that oregano oil may cause miscarriage or contractions in the uterus [21].

When used as directed, oregano oil should be safe. In too-high doses, it may have detrimental effects. This may be due in part to thymol, one of the phenols it contains. In high doses, thymol is a mild irritant which might affect the skin or internal organs

In low doses over a short period of time, oregano essential oil is considered generally safe. However, high doses may be toxic to the liver.

How much oil of oregano is too much?
Oregano oil can irritate mucous membranes of the throat, esophagus, and stomach, so it should never be taken with just water; a carrier oil helps mitigate these effects. She suggests just 50 to 80 milligrams (two or three drops) per dose

>Maybe my genes make me prone to candida.

If you have any red head or irish/celt heritage, or if you have European heritage, you likely have the genetic defects.

CANDF2 (Immunodeficiency 103)

A defect in CARD9 gene, 342 variants. Primary immunodeficiency characterized by increased susceptibility to fungal infections. Predisposition to Systemic and Invasive forms.

CANDF3

Chronic fungal nail infections.

CANDF4

Vaginal and Nail Candidiasis. Immune defect. Immune response 15% or less versus normal.
CANDF5 (Immunodeficiency 51)

Immune dysfunction in interleukin 17A,17F, 17A/F, 17E, responsible for responding to fungal infection. Frequent bacterial infections in the lungs. Connected to pancreatic cancer.

CANDF6

Gain of Function mutation in STAT1. Recurrent bacterial, viral, fungal, and mycoplasmal infections, disseminated dimorphic fungal infections, enteropathy with villous atrophy, and autoimmune disorders, such as hypothyroidism or diabetes mellitus. A subset of patients show apparently nonimmunologic features, including osteopenia, delayed puberty, and intracranial aneurysms. Laboratory studies show increased activation of gamma-interferon (IFNG; 147570)-mediated inflammation


CANDF7

A primary immunodeficiency disorder with altered immune responses and impaired clearance of fungal infections, selective against Candida. It is characterized by persistent and/or recurrent infections of the skin, nails and mucous membranes caused by organisms of the genus Candida, mainly Candida albicans.

CANDF8

Affiliated tissues include skin, and related phenotypes are macroglossia and seborrheic dermatitis

CANDF9

An important gene associated with Candidiasis, Familial, 9 is IL17RC (Interleukin 17 Receptor C). Affiliated tissues include skin, and related phenotypes are recurrent aphthous stomatitis and chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis

>Why don't they use Eris to replace Gemini's or Virgo's ruling planet?
Astrology is interlinked with astronomy.

To be sure of anything, you have to have observed it.

Eris was discovered only 2 decades ago; there is not enough evidence to say what its orbit is and thus what signs it transited or will transit beyond the data points already collected. You can liken this to projections about the COVID-19 vaccines; you'd be calling for people to take the vaccine after a "clinical trial" of a week.

The planetary bodies beyond Pluto and the Kuiper Belt have insufficient data to make assumptions even about what positions they were in historically, let alone what influence they exerted. So even though there's a possibility that any of them could have a true rulership relationship with Virgo or Taurus, we simply cannot be sure of it at all at this point.

>It seems stupid to have two of the sign share one
Yes.

>especially when it's a lame planet like Mercury
Mercury isn't lame, it's one of the most important.

>They already inserted Uranus, Neptune and Pluto arbitrarily
It wasn't that arbitrary, but more to the point there's been enough data collected to look back decades and centuries to make such pronouncements about what they mean.

>Does this planet have any current use in astrology?
Nothing credible. Pure speculation.

There's also the possibility Vir./Tau. rule an asteroid belt planet like Ceres, that's been underexplored.

>>33969443
I wish I could give you some tips, but it just happens naturally for me. Sometimes when I'm trying to think of things to write, I've induced it by getting ready for bed and keeping a notepad on my nightstand. It works best when I'm focusing on a topic I'm already working on, but that's not strictly speaking about aphantasia.

I think of approaching sleep on four different levels. Level 1 is waking conscious thought, level 2 is similar but less lucid (this is where most anxious thoughts hit me), level 3 is where the magic happens, where I feel like I could fall asleep at any time but I get crazy good visuals and can even command them to some extent by focusing, and level 4 is obviously sleep and dreaming.

The thing I struggle with is walking the tightrope between focusing on the visualizations and increased creativity versus becoming too aware and slipping up into levels 1 and 2 accidentally.

I struggle with insomnia a lot too, so it's tempting to me to simply fall asleep when the opportunity presents itself.

posts.com:
During the day or when I'm awake, I think in concepts and words. I can't picture anything in my mind. I've been trying for years. I've had a few breakthroughs in meditation - seeing something that looked like the ocean waves. But that's about it.

I have very vivid and visual dreams. Not always of course but sometimes. They're usually vivid enough for me to remember really mundane details that wouldn't matter, and sometimes they feel very real. I don't usually have nightmares but when I do, they're absolutely terrifying.

I had a lot of nightmares as a kid and during my teen years. Didn't dream at all in my early 20s because my doctor put me on Trazodone which I stayed on for about 8 years before deciding I can do without it. Dreams came back. Then I decided to quit smoking weed and the dreams came back full force.

I tend to dream most during naps rather than at night when I do a full 7-9 hour sleep.

I wish I could see the things I do in my dreams while awake, but my brain can't even picture a goddamn apple despite knowing what the fuck an apple looks like.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Love this topic. Maybe an apple is too difficult to start with. You can train the skill, there's nothing wrong with you. Start with a white square. Triangle. Simple shapes like that on the blackness of your closed eyelids. Don't try to conjure up an AR style hallucination overlaying the physical world just yet. Crawl before you sprint.
So, think of it this way: Sight, actual, physical sight with your eyeballs is a passive interaction. All the information is being fed directly to your whatever "visual cortex."
Visualization is an ACTIVE pursuit. You have to literally conjure up those said hallucinations. And even the humble white square on a black backdrop is a conjured hallucination. Simple as.
Perhaps you're actively engaging your visual cortex when you visualize, perhaps it's another part of the brain entirely. I don't know. I do know that the act of visualization is a verb, though.
Practice different simple shapes, then flicker through them as fast as you can like a Mario 3 Level flag.
What did you JUST recall when I said "Mario 3 level flag?" Did you glance to one side or the other and SEE it as you recalled it? Even if only for an instant? If not, What DID you just do in your head when you read that?
No matter, though, you get the idea. And once you can do the simple shapes, you can move on to complex images, moving scenes, audio, olfactory, tactile and so on. Give your car a big tall blower or something. A chariot race past your trailer court followed by the racers racing the other way, being chased by elephants. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1) Dreams are an oniric mirror of the real life and the mind of the dreamer. It is an extension of your consciousness while you are resting.
2) True interpretation requires intimate knowledge of the minute life of the dreamer and his mind. The dreamer holds the key to interpret his own dreams and figure out the correlation of the events in the dream to the corresponding situations in real life.
3) I consider dreams to be immersive "workshops" to work out issues, like a videogame's practice mode. Actions in dreams do not have consequences once you wake up. No one has ever been hospitalized because of an accident in a dream.
4) Dreams are not good or bad omens in and out of themselves. They do not predict the future. They have no hold on real life. They are not external messages from the spirit world*. You will not access "information" you are not already privy to in your real life, although some bits of it that you are aware of may take new forms and be combined and rearranged in creative ways. So-called "prophetic" dreams are either coincidences or self-fulfilled prophecies.
*I regretfully include this bit even though I hate to discount the possibility that dreams are a portal to or from an external extraordinary world. I have dreamed of my mother in a very positive way soon after her death and it was very comforting at the time as I believed it was her own soul contacting me. However I now hold the view that the dream world is entirely internally generated due to my life experience. I am not interested in denying other people's unexplained or paranormal experiences, but I cannot honestly support them either.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>33977272
5) However, revelations or certainties that have been brewing subconsciously in one's mind for a time may finally surface within a dream, and as such affect real life. In other words, you may access your intuition in a more vivid form.
6) Dreams are not always about life or death issues, but often about trivial situations. They are no less useful but their importance should not be exagerated.
7) Nightmares have a very positive connotation for the dreamer and should be embraced. They are simulations which prepares you psychologically for future difficulties and challenges. If you wake up from a nightmare and feel relieved that it is over, consider your day blessed.
8) Not all details in a dream have a profound meaning. There is a lot of randomly generated "noise" that is not worth pondering about, especially if you have no special emotional reaction to it within the dream. Dreams are not David Lynch movies, mathematical equations or puzzles to be solved, even though they certainly are cryptic, fickle and frustrating to interpret.
9) A good first step to interpret a dream is to focus on your emotional responses within them. The stronger the emotion, the more there is to take away from this part of the dream.
