My best friend recovered from alcoholism, it took him a fair amount of time, but he fully comitted to his methods and was 100% sucessful, he just continued following through until it was complete. The method went as followed:

He started to drink a pint of water every other alcoholic drink, and incorporated more fruit into his diet.
When he was ready to cut the alcohol out completely he started to replace it with fruit juice, because the body severely lacks the level of sugar the alcohol normally provides. The fruit juice will provide what a huge aspect of the physical craving used to rely on alcohol for.

My friend did this for himself and won his life back and tenfold, he has gone on to lead a much more fun, friend filled, fulfilling life, and has becomd an incredible, well rounded man with a great sense of humour and 5 star chef skills.

Take care, know that love surround you.

>>33973349
finding the cause, rather than treating the effect (alcoholism) is delicate work.

It's going to take time for you to understand why you consume the way you do, and no one here will answer that except you. Why do you drink? What does it do for you? Can you achieve that same effect doing something else?

tldr; if you believe strong enough, then you will drop it entirely.

You're already aware that it's causing an effect on your life that is undesirable, but you're still holding on to something.

The itch will pass. Let yourself discover what you are capable of when you support yourself, your good habits, when you are strong and when you are low.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm an alcoholic... well kinda. You see, it's been a battle figuring out HOW to quit. After trial and error here is what I can share:

-Tobacco and all other drugs must also be quit
-Treat the body like a temple
-You have to be good. Health is reserved for the good, ugliness and disease for the wicked
-You don't get to be a judgmental racist sorry
-You must exercise daily, walking and lifting weights to clear toxins
-Take raw garlic and onion for strength sometimes in the form of chilli or whatever, weakness causes relapse
-Make some fresh pico de gaio,
-Replace sugar with fruit juices, make some oatmeal or cream of wheat with butter and honey
-Keep sexual activity to a minimum, try to go 3 days at least
-It's a spiritual thing, you'll be tempted. For me I get flashes of demons with wings being frustrated that I'm not doing what they say
-You must practice some sort of spirituality. For me it's the awareness-watching-awareness method combined with the other things I mentioned. For Christians, it can be opening up the Bible and reading it, or praying for 1+ hours...

I don’t have a perfect answer but I can share what helped me finally quit drinking after having abused it for well over a decade
I addressed my drinking via EDMR with a therapist and I decided not to drink for two whole weeks just to see how I felt without it
It was a difficult two weeks, as drinking was one of the most stubborn of addictions for me to shake, and to cope I smoked hella weed whenever I wanted to drink
After those two weeks my body and mind felt so damn good, I didn’t want to spoil it by poisoning it with booze
The increased weed usage was only temporary during those two weeks to serve as a distraction from craving alcohol and I easily decreased back to smoking it once every few days
It’s impossible to not think about that thing you don’t want to think about. So you gotta replace it with something else to think about

I'm not sure what to say, the reason I stopped because I had enough of abusing my body and I had enough of regretting stupidity. I want my mind and body clear and healthy before the stains set in any more with age. I'm only a few weeks into sobriety (including from weed) but aside from bouts of boredom here and there I'm thoroughly enjoying it.
For it to be as easy as this, you need to like yourself enough to want to like yourself, and you have to have hope in life. This is of course a very personal variable. I wish I knew what could inspire you and light a fire in your core, not one of chemicals but from your soul.

Something that I have that some people don't is regular access to the woods - maybe that's something you could take up if you don't already, they aren't lying about how nature has a balancing and therapeutic effect on the mind. Set goals for hikes, bring some food for a little picnic, and while you're out there, think about what you want in life. Talk to yourself out loud. I find talking to myself out loud is very fucking helpful for processing things that happen in my life.

And maybe a less healthy coping mechanism that I have is imagining someone who's opinion I value looking at what I see through my eyes on a little television set in another dimension. That's pretty encouraging to act my best.

•Avoid making the same query repeatedly and/or to different readers in a short period of time, as this may lead to more confusion.
•Provide feedback when applicable and be considerate to the reader. We're a growing community, many readers are starting and need to know what they are doing right or wrong. Let's help each other to improve. >>33972623

posts.name: Ghost
posts.com:
>>33976231
Are you planning on doing readings just for yourself or for others?

I think that learning tarot and working with your intuition in that way, involves skills you can begin adopting in your life now. If you know that you're in a tough spot then I'd say ask yourself if you feel you can practice responsibly and be self aware about that? If the answer is no, I would say that you need to create some routines that centre around spiritual and mental hygiene, then revisit this in a month. Hygiene could be only delving into the occult or divination for just a few set hours a day and redirecting your thoughts the rest of the time. It could also mean meditation, or taking responsibility for other areas you've been neglecting. I say that because divination will not help you feel in control of your life on it's own, it just gives more information to work with.

There could be other forms of divination you could explore too. I really like bibliomancy as a more lowkey alternative to tarot that doesn't involve so much interpretation and can get you in touch with your intuition.

A few things I've found are important; being able to ground yourself, finding a balance between logic and emotion, opening yourself up to diverse experiences, thinking in a dialectical way, separating yourself entirely from readings if they're for another person. Doing readings for yourself, with a limit of say, one a day is a good way to start out learning and using your intuition. It should be a self reflection exercise though to start with.

It's very typical advise but meditation can really help you find the presence of mind needed to regulate and present enough to receive information through divination with clarity.

page of swords
king of wands rev
wheel of fortune rev
hermit rev
You're less codependent than you really think. Still, there's an uneasiness in your own energy. This partially feels sexual in nature. It's like you constantly want something wilder and you like women who personify this trait because you've been subconsciously or consciously wanting to embody this trait yourself. You have a lot of moral constraints and while this is a good thing usually, it can make you a little rigid and judgmental at times.
